Award.AwardTitle: Syncretizing Science and Art Into Ultra-Precision Machine Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research award provides funding for the development of a set of tools for designing high precision flexure mechanisms. Flexure mechanisms are the central part of numerous precision machinery that are used in a wide range of science and engineering applications. Since the current approaches are inadequate for designing these kinds of machines, this project aims to develop kinematic and mechanism theories and computational tools that analyze complex flexure mechanisms and synthesize ones for prescribed design requirements. The valuable practical design experience from engineers will be fully exploited via a digital catalogue of commonly used flexure elements, joints and building blocks that will be carefully designed and analyzed. These theories, tools and design catalogue will be integrated into a dedicated computer-aided design program with advanced human-computer-interfaces.

If successful, the new design tools will significantly speed up the design process and shorten the research and development cycle and lead to innovation of many more highly precision devices such as nanopositioners, nanomanipulators, MEMS scanning mirrors. These devices further enable scientists in a wide range of fields such as biology, nanotechnology, astronomy explore the unknown world more efficiently. By bringing the research results into undergraduate and graduate curriculum, we hope to educate the next generation precision engineers with this innovative design tool. To maximize the impact of this research, we will disseminate the research results to industry, academia and general public by (1) distributing flexure design software and the design catalogue, (2) interacting with scientists in national labs, and (3) organizing workshops at national and international conferences. We will also develop a summer camp and interactive virtual reality demonstration programs to outreach k-12, pre-freshman and women students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project is to develop a set of theoretical and computational tools for designing high precision flexure mechanisms.  Since the current approaches are inadequate for designing these kinds of machines, we have developed kinematic and mechanism theories and computational tools that analyze complex flexure mechanisms and synthesize ones for prescribed design requirements. These design theories and tools have been integrated into dedicated computer-aided design programs. The outcomes of this research are detailed in below.

Intellectual merits:

(a) A screw theory based approach for type synthesis of compliant parallel mechanisms (PMs) have been developed. By this method, we can generate a catalogue of flexure elements, flexure joints, sub-assemblies and compliant mechanisms that satisfy a given set of motion requirements. This new synthesis theory plays a fundamental role in the conceptual design of compliant mechanisms that will be a central part of precision machinery.

(b) Precision or accuracy is essential to numerous flexure mechanisms. We studied how the accuracy of the pseudo-rigid-body (PRB) models is affected by the changes of beam parameters such as deformation on length and cross section of the beam. We also investigated to quantify effects of short beams and soft materials on PRB models. Also a 3-spring revolute-prismatic-revolute pseudo-rigid-body model for compliant joints made of soft material is proposed. The traditional PRB models based on long thin Euler beams failed to capture this elongation effect.  We have developed an optimization process to determine the optimal values of the parameters of the PRB model for improving the modeling accuracy.

(c) We have developed DAS-2D and DAS-3D, computer programs for kinetostatic synthesis for design automation of planar and spatial compliant mechanisms respectively. A systematic approach for building the necessary equations that are based on screw theory and linear elastic theory is proposed. A digital library of commonly used flexure elements have been developed and integrated into DAS-3D.

(d) Moreover, we applied the developed design theories and tools to solve practical problems on precision machine design. For instance, we designed a novel planar XY positioning stage synthesizing the benefits of parallel and serial kinematic constraint. This design significantly reduced parasitic rotation angles. As another example, we studied the workspace optimization of a MEMS flexure-based hexapod nano-positioner device.  A novel adaptive genetic algorithm has been developed to conduct the single and biobjective optimization for maximum translational and rotational workspace.

 

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of this research project focused on two aspects: (a) dissemination of the design tools resulted from this project via organizing workshop, summer schools and conference presentations, (b) integration of research and education and (c) engage undergraduate students in research.

(a) In terms of dissemination of research results, PI and his research group has organized a tutorial on design and analysis of compliant mechanisms at 2015 ASME IDETC held in Boston, MA. PI gave a four-hour lecture to 85 registered participants. The interactive design software called DAS-2D resulted from the project was distributed to all participants. Furthermore, a new dedicated website has been built to disseminate the research results to a broader community. As the chair of 2016 ASME Mechanisms and Robotics (M&RD) Conference, PI has led ASME M&R committee to organize a kinematics summer school on compliant mechanisms which was held on August 20-21, 2016 in Charlotte, NC. PI was invited to give a lecture on design methods, theories and applications of compliant mechanisms.

(b) With regard to integration of research and education. PI has already integrated the screw theory based design approach into a graduate level course ME 7751 Advanced Kinematics and Mechanisms. This course is offered in Autumn 2015 and will be offered every other year. Also PI has offered a new course ME 5751 Design and Manufacturing of Compliant Mechanisms and Robots to undergraduate curriculum in Mechanical Engineering program at OSU. In this course, research results on pseudo-rigid-body models have been taught and design tool DAS-2D was distributed to the class to solve practical compliant mechanism design problem. Students worked on a design project on mechanism design in a team environment. All design teams will participate a competition during the final week. This course has been offered in spring 2015 and spring 2016. And it will be continued to be offered each spring semester.

(c) As for engaging undergraduate students in research, PI has been regularly hiring UG to assist graduate student on research tasks, especially in digital modeling, physical prototyping and testing via REU supplemental fund. PI have also leveraged internal sources such as scholarship for UG honor thesis to engage UG students on relevant research tasks. By far, at least six UG research assistants have been hired and at least three UG honor theses whose topic is relevant to this project.
